title: Citi Journalistic Excellence Award 2011 Celebrates Second Year of High-Quality Financial Reporting
summary: Hong Kong – Citi Hong Kong today announced the 2011 results of the Citi Journalistic Excellence Award (CJEA), which recognizes quality reporting and the role of media in enabling a transparent and internationally-competitive financial market for Hong Kong.
tag-1: Citi Journalistic Excellence Award 2011 Celebrates Second Year of High-Quality Financial Reporting
tag-3: Hong Kong – Citi Hong Kong today announced the 2011 results of the Citi Journalistic Excellence Award (CJEA), which recognizes quality reporting and the role of media in enabling a transparent and internationally-competitive financial market for Hong Kong.
tag-4: The prestigious global competition spans close to 40 countries, selecting 20 outstanding journalists on the basis of a published article on a financial or economic subject. Veteran journalist Sandy Li from South China Morning Post, this year's Hong Kong's winner, won the first runner-up title in the 2010 competition.
tag-5: "Citi is committed to rewarding excellence and raising the bar for financial reporting in Hong Kong," Citi Country Officer for Hong Kong Shengman Zhang said. "We are excited to present this prestigious global competition in Hong Kong for the second year. The Citi Journalistic Excellence Award is a career-enhancing competition that highlights the importance of quality reporting to maintain the fair and open business environment upon which Hong Kong's economic success depends."
tag-6: Li won CJEA Hong Kong 2011 with an article entitled "Shantytowns Are No Place to Call Home," published in "South China Morning Post" on June 11, 2010. Representing Hong Kong, she will join the 19 other country winners at a 10-day study tour hosted by the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism in New York in June 2011.
tag-7: The three other Hong Kong winners for 2011 were first runner-up Denise Tsang of South China Morning Post and second runner-ups Hidy Or of iMoney magazine and Eric Ng of South China Morning Post. Professor Francis Lui, Head and Professor, Department of Economics, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, and head judge for CJEA Hong Kong 2011, said, "Being a judge for the second year, I am encouraged to observe a consistency in maturity and diversity of articles to assess in both years. The judges unanimously found passion for accuracy and critical thinking, thorough analysis and evidence of deep understanding of critical issues. I bestow high praise on Citi for its commitment in organizing this prestigious competition to reward our hard-working media and inspire them to raise standards even more."
tag-8: In addition to Professor Lui, there are others who gave their time and expertise as part of the independent CJEA jury. These included Mr. Bernard Chan, President of Asia Financial Holdings Limited; Mr. Philip Chen, Managing Director of Hang Lung Properties Limited; Professor Stephen Cheung, Dean of the School of Business, Hong Kong Baptist University; Mr. Paul Chow, Chairman of The Hong Kong Cyberport Management Company Limited and member of the inaugural judging panel; and Mr. Stanley Hui, Chief Executive Officer, of Airport Authority.
tag-9: The 20 international CJEA winners will spend 10 days in New York where they will take part in seminars with leading Columbia University faculty members, engage in discussions with senior academics and policy-makers, and visit key financial institutions such as the New York Stock Exchange, the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, Bloomberg, and the Federal Reserve Bank. In addition to sponsoring this study tour prize, Citi will also award cash prizes to all three Hong Kong finalists: HK$10,000 for the winner, HK$6,000 for the first runner-up, and HK$4,000 for the second runner-up.
tag-10: Since CJEA's inception in 1982, more than 300 talented journalists from over 100 media outlets in 37 countries have enhanced their careers through participation in the study seminar. CJEA Hong Kong 2010 is sponsored by Citi Hong Kong and administered by Columbia Graduate School of Journalism.
